DataElement.preferredDefinition: The class of clinical or laboratory procedure(s) used to determine the secondary disease diagnosis.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The coexistence of two or more disease processes.:The clinical or laboratory procedure(s) used in the determination of a disease diagnosis.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The coexistence of two or more disease processes.

Concepts.definition: The coexistence of two or more disease processes.

Property.preferredDefinition: The clinical or laboratory procedure(s) used in the determination of a disease diagnosis.

Concepts.definition: The clinical or laboratory procedure(s) used in the determination of a disease diagnosis.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities._A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A biopsy involving the removal of a core tissue containing bone spicules and hematopoietic elements embedded in the marrow stroma.  This procedure is done in the hip area mainly for the diagnosis and evaluation of neoplastic and non-neoplastic hematopoietic disorders (e.g. anemias, leukemias, lymphomas) and the evaluation of the spread of solid tumors (e.g. carcinomas, sarcomas) and lymphomas for therapeutic purposes.

Concepts.definition: A biopsy involving the removal of a core tissue containing bone spicules and hematopoietic elements embedded in the marrow stroma.  This procedure is done in the hip area mainly for the diagnosis and evaluation of neoplastic and non-neoplastic hematopoietic disorders (e.g. anemias, leukemias, lymphomas) and the evaluation of the spread of solid tumors (e.g. carcinomas, sarcomas) and lymphomas for therapeutic purposes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A nuclear imaging method used to evaluate pathological bone metabolism.

Concepts.definition: A nuclear imaging method used to evaluate pathological bone metabolism.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

Concepts.definition: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 2023.3.21 Alt VM added per ticket request CADSR0002164. ak

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An element with atomic symbol Ga, atomic number 31, and atomic weight 69.7. A rare silvery (usually trivalent) metallic element; brittle at low temperatures but liquid above room temperature; occurs in trace amounts in bauxite and zinc ores.

Concepts.definition: An element with atomic symbol Ga, atomic number 31, and atomic weight 69.7. A rare silvery (usually trivalent) metallic element; brittle at low temperatures but liquid above room temperature; occurs in trace amounts in bauxite and zinc ores.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Any technology or method that aids in the visualization of any biological process, cell, tissue or organ for use in screening, diagnosis, surgical procedures or therapy.

Concepts.definition: Any technology or method that aids in the visualization of any biological process, cell, tissue or organ for use in screening, diagnosis, surgical procedures or therapy.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: 5.8.17 Changed NCIm concept to NCIt concept per NMDP request. mc

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide amazingly clear and detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Concepts.definition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The medical science, and specialty practice, concerned with all aspects of disease, but with special reference to the essential nature, causes, and development of abnormal conditions, as well as the structural functional changes that result from disease processes.  Informally used to mean the result of such an examination.

Concepts.definition: The medical science, and specialty practice, concerned with all aspects of disease, but with special reference to the essential nature, causes, and development of abnormal conditions, as well as the structural and functional changes that result from the disease processes. Informally used to mean the result of such an examination.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.

Concepts.definition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Positron Emission Tomography and Computed Tomography Scan
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An imaging technique that utilizes positron emission tomography and computed tomography in a single machine.

Concepts.longName: Positron Emission Tomography and Computed Tomography Scan
Concepts.definition: An imaging technique that utilizes positron emission tomography and computed tomography in a single machine.

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Positron Emission Tomography and Magnetic Resonance Imaging
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An imaging technique that utilizes positron emission tomography and magnetic resonance imaging in a single machine.

Concepts.longName: Positron Emission Tomography and Magnetic Resonance Imaging
Concepts.definition: An imaging technique that utilizes positron emission tomography and magnetic resonance imaging in a single machine.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A substance sometimes found in an increased amount in the blood, other body fluids, or tissues and which may mean that a certain type of cancer is in the body. Examples of tumor markers include CA 125 (ovarian cancer), CA 15-3 (breast cancer), CEA (ovarian, lung, breast, pancreas, and gastrointestinal tract cancers), and PSA (prostate cancer). Also called biomarker.

Concepts.definition: A substance present in or produced by a tumor or by the host, that can be used for differentiating neoplastic from normal tissue based on measurements in body fluids, secretions, cells, and/or tissues. Markers are used in diagnosis, staging and prognosis of cancer, provide an estimation of tumor burden, and serve for monitoring effects of therapy, detecting recurrence, localization of tumors, and screening in general populations.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: High frequency sound, generally with a frequency greater than 20,000 Hz.

Concepts.definition: High frequency sound, generally with a frequency greater than 20,000 Hz.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A radiographic procedure using the emission of x-rays to form an image of the structure penetrated by the radiation.

Concepts.definition: A radiographic procedure using the emission of x-rays to form an image of the structure penetrated by the radiation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.

Concepts.definition: Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 7/8/22 added alt name of NA for CCTG cjl;

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not provided or available.

Concepts.definition: Not provided or available.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 10/10/23 changed Long Name from "Not Stated" to match NCIt Preferred name and current caDSR concept Long Name of "Not Reported" per Brenda.Janice . LS

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

Concepts.definition: The removal of tissue specimens or fluid from the living body for microscopic examination, performed to establish a diagnosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The fluid that flows in and around the hollow spaces of the brain and spinal cord, and between two of the meninges (the thin layers of tissue that cover and protect the brain and spinal cord). CSF is made by tissue called the choroid plexus in the ventricles (hollow spaces) in the brain.

Concepts.definition: The fluid that is contained within the brain ventricles, the subarachnoid space and the central canal of the spinal cord.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Technique or procedure for manipulation of cells and analysis of cell properties and subcellular features.

Concepts.definition: Technique or procedure for manipulation of cells and analysis of cell properties and subcellular features.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion and auscultation. The purpose is to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for an individual's health assessment.

Concepts.definition: A systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion and auscultation. The purpose is to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for an individual's health assessment.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Updated definition to match current NCIt. mc 4.23.19

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A surgical procedure in which tissue is removed.

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of an organ or a part of an organ.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Any specific activity undertaken during the course of a clinical study or research protocol.
